coredata.dc:title: Vibrational energy relaxation of O2 in liquid mixtures with Ar and N2
coredata.dc:creator: Faltermeier, B.
Protz, R.
Maier, Max
Werner, E.
coredata.dc:description:
Abstract
The relaxation rate of the first vibrational level of O2 in the electronic ground state was determined in liquid O2/Ar and O2/N2 mixtures. Ar and N2 were found to be inefficient in de-exciting O2. The oxygen relaxation rate decreases non-linearly with decreasing O2 concentration. The experimental results are discussed in terms of a model using the pair distribution functions of liquid mixtures.

xocs:doc.xocs:rawtext: Volume 74, number 3 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 15 September 1980 VIBRATIONAL ENERGY RELAXATION OF 0^ IN LIQUID MIXTURES WITH Ar AND N^ B FALTERMEIER, R. PROTZ, Max MAIER Fakultat fur Physik Ifnnersitat Regensburg, Regensburg. Germany and E. WERNER Institut fur ilieorctische Physik. Umversitat Hannover. Hannover. Germany Received 2 June 1980 The relaxation rate of the first vibrational level of 0; in the electronic ground state was determined in liquid Oa/Ar and O^/N^ mixtures Ar and N'2 were found to be inefficient in de-exciting O;. The oxygen relaxation rate decreases non-linear- ly with decreasing 0; concentration The experimental results are discussed in terms of a model using the pair distribution functions of liquid mixtures 1. Introduction The problem of vibrational energy relaxation in simple liquids has been under investigation for several ^.ears [1 8] . Liquid mixtures have been employed to study energy-transfer processes between different molecules- The vibrational energy relaxation time was measured in liquid Ar with small concentrations of H^ [9], in liquid H:, doped with HD and D-^ [10], and in liquid N3 doped with a variety of simple mole- cules (e g. C>2, CO, H^ and D^) and with polyatomic molecules [11 13]. In all these invesugations the concentration of the dopants was less than 0.05. In this letter, we report on investigations of the relaxation of the first vibrational level in the electron- ic ground state of0^ in liquid mixtures with Ar and N- . The oxygen mole fraction was varied from 0.25 to 1. The 03 vibrational relaxation rate decreased non-linearly with decreasing 0-; concentration. The effect of Ar and N3 molecules on the vibrational de- activation of0- was found to be small. The vibra- tional relaxation in the mixtures will be discussed in terms of a model involving the pair distribution func- tions of the liquid mixtures. 2. Experimental The apparatus and the purification procedure have been described in detail in ref. [5]. We briefly discuss the principle of our measurements. Oxygen molecules are excited to the l^(v'=0) and l^a(u'= 1) states by absorption of theUght pulse of a Nd: YAG laser. ^g is the lowest-lying excited electronic state and v the vibrational quantum number in this state. Rap- id relaxation occurs and populates the first vibration- al level u = 1 of the electronic ground state ^S The vibrational energy relaxation rate of O-i in the ^S^u = 1) state is investigated. A time-delayed ruby laser probes the decay of the vibrational population by spontaneous anti-Stokes Rarnan scattering. The anti- Stokes energy 35 is measured as a function of delay time tQ between pump pulse and probe pulse. A log- arithmic plot of gs versus fp represents a straight line. From the slope of the curve we obtain the vi- brational energy relaxation time T'. 0-, is known to produce homogeneous mixtures with Ar and N3. The mixtures were prepared in the following way: The gas with lower density was liquefied in the sample cell of a continuous-flow cryostat. Then the higher-density gas was condensed on top of it (densities p(N^) < p(0.,) < p(Ar)). The samples were 425 Volume 74, number 3 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 15 September 1980 allowed to stand for several hours to ensure homo- geneous mixing The concentration of the mixture was determined by measuring the absorption of He Ne laser light. The 07 absorption coefficient at 633 nm has a nearly quadratic dependence on 0^ concen- tration [14]. This has been checked by preparing mixtures of known concentration 3. Results Measurements of the vibrational energy relaxation rate k = 1/r' ofO-? in liquid O^/Ar and O^/N^ mix- tures of different concentrations were earned out. The 03 relaxation rate k(x) in the mixtures was nor- malized to the rate k( 1) of neat liquid oxygen. The dependence of the normalized 03 relaxation rate k(x)fk( 1) on mole fraction x of 07 in the mixtures is shown in fig. 1 for Of/Ar (o) and O^/N^ ( ) sam- -s 05 Oz mole fraction x Fig. 1. Normalized 0; relaxation rate A(t)/A'(l) of liquid O;/ Ar (o) and Oz/Nz ( ) mixtures versus mole fraction A- ofO; (at T= 77 K). The solid and broken lines correspond to Oa/ Ar mixtures and the dotted and dash-dotted lines to Oa/Nz mixtures The L'nes have been calculated according to eqs (4)-(6). pies at fixed temperature T= 77 K. Measurements at low oxygen mole fractions (x < 0.2) are difficult because the oxygen absorption at the Nd - YAG la- ser frequency is small and the number of excited mol- ecules is too small to be detected with our measuring system The following results are obtained from fig 1 (i) There is a non-linear dependence ofk on mole fraction x of 0^. which is similar for O^/Ar and O-,/ N3 mixtures. The normalized relaxation rate de- creases from \(k = 400 s~1) for neat liquid 0^ to 0.15 (60 s-1) for an 0, mole fraction ofx = 0.3. For rarefied O^/Ar gas mixtures a linear concentration dependence is expected [15 17]. The concentration dependence ofk for the gas and liquid mixtures is discussed in section 4 (n) Extrapolation ofk(x) to 0^ mole fractions x -> 0 yields small rate constants k(0) for the de-exci- tation ofC>2 by Ar and N3, indicating that the effect of both molecules is small 4. Discussion There exist several theories of vibrational energy relaxation in the liquid phase (for references see ret. [5] ). The vibrational relaxation rate of neat liquid 0^ has been discussed in ref [5] using a cell model with movable walls Delalande and Gale [7] presented a semiclassical model for the vibrational energy relax- ation rate in terms of the pair distribution function of the liquid. For bquid hydrogen and deuterium, the calculated density dependence was found to be in good agreement with experiment over a wide range of densities and temperatures [6 8]. The cell model described the experimental results for H^ only with- in a limited density range. We discuss our experimental results using an exten- sion of the semiclassical model of ref. [7] to liquid mixtures [9]. In this model the intermolecular poten- tial is supposed to consist of an infinitely repulsive hard core of diameter a plus an attractive well. The process of vibrational de-excitation, i.e. the transfer of vibrational energy to translation, is assumed to be localized on the hard core. The internal degrees of freedom of the collision partners are neglected. The vibrational relaxation rate fcg, of a neat liquid is then related to the pair distribution function g^ for the 426 Volume 74, number 3 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 15 September 1980 model fluid at contact distance o [7]: ^""ei^e.- <1) The subscript ei characterizes excited molecule ground-state molecule interactions, n, is the number density of molecules in the neat liquid and Kg, is the de-excitation rate constant per molecule. For a rare- fied hard-sphere gasgg, = 1, i e. the relaxation rate is given byn,K^ The extension of the model to mixtures of simple hquids is straightforward [9] when V T energy trans- fer is dominant and V V energy exchange is neglect- ed. It is assumed that this condition is fulfilled not only in O^/Ar mixtures but also in good approxima- tion in O^/N^ mixtures. The 0^ relaxation rate k in a mixture with components i and J is then given by [9] k=k^k^. (2) frg, is the 0? C>2 relaxation rate and k the 0? Ar (or 0? N->) relaxation rate. Using eq (1) we find k as a function of0;> mole fraction x: k(x) = xnK^g^x) + (1 - X)HK^(X). (3) Here^elOO and^g(x) are the O^-O^ and 0? Ar (or O^ N-?) pair distribution functions at contact, which depend on the oxygen mole fraction x. The number density n in the mixture is calculated from the values 77, of neat liquid oxygen and n. of neat liquid Ar (or N->) using the relation n(x)=xn +(1 -x)n (4) The deviations of the values ofn calculated from eq. (4) from the measured values [18] are smaller than 1%. In rarefied gas mixtures the pair distribution functions^, ^gg, %; 1, leading to a linear concentra- tion dependence for k [see eq. (3)]. For a comparison with experimental results, it is convenient to normalize the relaxation rate k of mix- tures [eq. (3)] to that of neat liquid 0-? and to ex- press Kq/Kg, by k(0)/k(l). k(0) and k(\) are the re- laxation rates of infinitely diluted O^ and neat liquid OT, respectively. We obtain k(x)_ "OOge^) n(x)g^x)k(0) k(l) x "^,,(1) (1 x) n^O)k(l) (5) give a good representation of the behaviour of liquids. Using the expression for the pair distribution func- tion obtained by Camahan and Starling [19] , the model was successfully applied to the explanation of the experimental results for liquid hydrogen and deuterium [6 8]. For an explanation of our results in the mixtures, we used the pair distribution function for hard-sphere molecules with diameter a. The Camahan Starling expression for the pair distribution function has been extended to mixtures [20]. The analytic expression for g^, at contact is given by ej 1 ^"i ^ = - +3 J - -?3 ".^Jd-^)2 .l{-a^\~ ?22 V^V (l-?3)3" (6a) g^ is obtained by writing a. = o, in eq. (6a). Forgg, and g^ we have ^=(7inf6)[xa^+(l -x)a^] and (6b) It has been shown [7] that hard-sphere molecules ?3 = (7T /6) [xa^ + (1 - x} a^ ]. (6c) Here, we assume that the hard-sphere diameters of O? and C>2 are the same (tig = CT,) and the concentra- tion of excited oxygen molecules is small compared to that of the other components of the mixture. The 0^ mole fraction x enters the pair distribution func- tion via the packing fractions of both components [eq. (6c)]. The x-dependence of^g, andgg, is strong- ly related to the difference in the hard-sphere diam- eters o, and CT [eqs. (5b) and (6c)] and the number density n of the mixtures [eq. (4)]. The calculation of the pair distribution functions at contact requires knowledge of the hard-sphere di- ameters. In refs. [6 9] excellent agreement between calculation and experiment on liquid H^, D-,, and Ar/H^ was obtained by taking the hard-sphere diam- eter close to the Lennard-Jones parameter CT|J . As a Grst guess we used, therefore, the mean values of the Lennard-Jones parameters OIJ from ref. [21]: 0, = <Tu(07) = 3.50 X 10-8 cm; o,(Ar) = Ou(Ar) = 3.42 X 10-8 cm; (J/N:,) = <Tu(N2) = 3.71 X 10-8 cm. With these numbers the broken and dotted lines in fig. 1 have been calculated according to eqs. (4) (6) 427 Volume 74, number 3 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 15 September 1980 for O^/Ar and (^N2 mixtures. There are significant deviations from the experimental points. Next we used a value of a. = 3.8 X 10~8 cm For 0-7 which is considerably larger than CT^J but has been found in ref. [5] to describe the temperature dependence of the vibrational relaxation rate of neat liquid oxygen o,(Ar) and o,(N->) were again taken equal to their Lennard-Jones parameters. Good agreement between the calculated curves (solid and dash-dotted lines in fig. 1) and the experimental points was obtained. In the calculations, the ratio k(0)/k(l) has been fitted to obtain the best agreement between the cal- culated curves and the measured points. The optimum value for liquid 0-,/'N-, mixtures was &(0) = 22 s~1, which should be compared with the value of 35 s~1 found in ref. [11]. In liquid O^/Ar mixtures, the op- timum value of&(0) = 12 s~1 is smaller by about a factor of 33 tlian A'(l) for neat liquid 0-7. Measure- ments in O;; Ar mixtures in the gas phase have shown that at high temperatures (T> 1000 K) the 0?-Ar relaxation rate is smaller by about one order of mag- nitude than the O^ O? relaxation rate [16,17]. It was suggested in ref. [16] that this may be due to a steeper slope of the repulsive core of the 03 03 sys- tem or to the extra energy in rotation contributing to the 03-03 rate. The calculations show that our experimental re- sults cannot be explained when all hard-sphere diam- eters a of0->, Ar. and N3 are taken close to the cor- responding Lennard-Jones parameters CT^J . This is in contrast to the observations in liquid H-,, D"? and Ar/ H-, [6 9] We believe that there are additional phe- nomena leading to deviations from the linear concen- tration dependence of the 0^ mixtures which are not contained in the simple hard-sphere model. Such phenomena which should be included in a more so- phisticated treatment are (i) more realistic intermo- lecular potentials, (li) collision pairs or dimers [22, 23], (in) angular correlations in liquid O^. Dilution of liquid 0^ by Ar or N3 may influence points (n) and (ui) and could contribute to the non-linear con- centration dependence In the case ofO^/N^ mixtures V V energy trans- fer between O^ and N3 requires special discussion. The vibrational frequency of N3 (2331 cm~1) is con- siderably larger than that ofO^ (1556 cm""1). Vibra- tional energy transfer from 03 to N3 should be small at liquid-nitrogen temperature (7~= 77 K). It has been shown, however, that vibrational energy transfer be- tween 0^ and N3 may occur via nearly resonant higher vibrational levels of both molecules [11] .When V V transfer is important a non-linear dependence of the relaxation rate on concentration may occur even in gas mixtures under appropriate conditions [15]. It is difficult at present to estimate the influ- ence of V V energy transfer on our results in liquid O^/N^ mixtures since the transfer routes and the relevant time constants are not known. head.ce:title: Vibrational energy relaxation of O2 in liquid mixtures with Ar and N2

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: The relaxation rate of the first vibrational level of O2 in the electronic ground state was determined in liquid O2/Ar and O2/N2 mixtures. Ar and N2 were found to be inefficient in de-exciting O2. The oxygen relaxation rate decreases non-linearly with decreasing O2 concentration. The experimental results are discussed in terms of a model using the pair distribution functions of liquid mixtures.

ce:other-ref.ce:textref: C. Delalande and G.M. Gale, J. Chem. Phys., to be published.
